THIS AWARD TO HEALTHY SCHOOLS CAMPAIGN (HSC) WILL SUPPORT SPACE TO GROW, CHICAGO'S GREEN SCHOOLYARDS INITIATIVE AND AN INNOVATIVE RESPONSE TO THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND HISTORIC DISINVESTMENT ON CHICAGO NEIGHBORHOODS, SCHOOLS AND STUDENTS. THE SCHOOLYARDS USE GREEN STORMWATER INFRASTRUCTURE (GSI) TO BOOST COMMUNITY RESILIENCE IN HISTORICALLY UNDER-INVESTED, FLOOD-PRONE COMMUNITIES IN CHICAGO. HSC'S WORK ENSURES THAT EACH SPACE TO GROW SCHOOL COMMUNITY HAS A VOICE IN THE DESIGN AND PLANS FOR THEIR NEW SCHOOLYARD, PROVIDES NATURE-BASED AND CLIMATE RESILIENCE EDUCATION TO FOSTER GENERATIONS OF ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS AND WORKS TO ENSURE THE GSI IS WELL MAINTAINED OVER TIME. THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE HSC STAFF TO:   -- ENGAGE AND WORK CLOSELY WITH STUDENTS (UNDER GUIDANCE OF THEIR TEACHERS AND PARENTS/CAREGIVERS), EDUCATORS, SCHOOL STAFF, PARENTS, CAREGIVERS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO IMPLEMENT A COMMUNITY DESIGN PROCESS FOR AT LEAST 25 NEW SPACE TO GROW SCHOOLYARDS.  -- PROVIDE EDUCA

TEXAS DOES NOT CONSIDER CLIMATE CHANGE WHEN PLANNING FOR ITS WATER SUPPLIES. THIS IS AN ISSUE BECAUSE A WARMING CLIMATE IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE EVAPORATION; INCREASE WATER DEMAND; DECREASE SOIL MOISTURE; DECREASE WATER RUNNING INTO OUR STREAM, RIVERS, AND RESERVOIRS; AND DECREASE WATER PERCOLATING TO OUR AQUIFERS. CLIMATE CHANGE'S IMPACTS TO WATER RESOURCES WILL HAVE PROFOUND EFFECTS ON OUR AGRICULTURE, INDUSTRY, MUNICIPALITIES, AND ENVIRONMENT. TO INFORM CITIZENS, PLANNERS, DECISION MAKERS, AND POLICYMAKERS, TEXAS STATE UNIVERSITY IS IMPLEMENTING A MULTI- YEAR PROJECT TO (1) DEVELOP ACTIONABLE, DOWN-SCALED CLIMATE PROJECTIONS FOR THE STATE (CORRECTIONS TO THE GLOBAL MODEL PROJECTIONS TO BETTER REFLECT LOCAL CONDITIONS); (2) ASSESS WHAT THESE PROJECTIONS MEAN FOR WATER RESOURCES AND THE ENVIRONMENT; AND (3) PROVIDE A POLICY ROADMAP FOR INDIVIDUALS, COMMUNITIES, AND THE STATE TO PREPARE TEXAS FOR THE CHALLENGES AHEAD TO OUR WATER RESOURCES, ECONOMY, AND ENVIRONMENT. RAINFALL AND GROUNDWATER CONTAIN NATURALLY OCCURRING STABLE ISOTOPES OF OXYGEN AND HYDROGEN, AND THE AMOUNT OF THESE ISOTOPES IN A WATER SAMPLE VARIES RELATED TO CHANGES IN CLIMATE. EVERY RAINDROP IS UNIQUE IN ITS HISTORY, FROM EVAPORATION FROM THE OCEAN, TO CLOUDS, TO THE PRECIPITATION (AS RAIN AND SNOW) THAT FALLS IN LAS VEGAS AND OTHER REGIONS, AND THE STABLE ISOTOPES PROVIDE A 'FINGERPRINT' OF THE RAIN'S ORIGINS.  A WATER ISOTOPE ANALYZER BRINGS EXCEPTIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN BOTH RESEARCH AND TEACHING FOR STUDENTS AT UNLV, AND FOR SCIENTISTS IN SOUTHERN NEVADA. THE PROPOSED INSTRUMENTATION WOULD PROVIDE CONTEXT FOR UNDERSTANDING MODERN CLIMATE CONTROLS ON THE HYDROLOGIC CYCLE IN THE ARID SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES AND PERMIT MORE ACCURATE FORECASTING OF FUTURE WATER RESOURCES VIA THE APPLICATION OF ISOTOPES IN ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES. THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED WORK IS TO UNDERSTAND THE CLIMATIC CONTROLS ON RAINFALL OXYGEN AND HYDROGEN ISOTOPE VALUES, TO SUPPORT INTERPRETATIONS OF PAL

PURPOSE: TO SUPPORT FOUR DISTINCT RESEARCH AND STUDENT TRAINING PROGRAMS PRIMARILY THROUGH: A) THE ACQUISITION OF RESEARCH INSTRUMENTS, B) GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT STIPENDS, AND C) SALARY SUPPORT FOR A 12 MONTH FIELD PROGRAMS MANAGER.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE FOUR PROGRAMS CONSIST OF: BLUE CRAB FIELD SURVEY, COASTAL CARBON CYCLE MONITORING, SHELLFISH AQUACULTURE GENETICS AND BREEDING, AND ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURAL RESOURCE ECONOMICS. THE BLUE CRAB FIELD SURVEY WILL ENGAGE STUDENTS WITH THE ADMINISTRATION OF A BLUE CRAB MONITORING SURVEY THAT HAS HISTORICALLY PROVIDED CRITICAL INFORMATION ON LONG TERM POPULATION DYNAMICS IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY. THE COASTAL CARBON CYCLE MONITORING PROJECT WILL TRAIN GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND COASTAL CARBON CYCLING THROUGH LONG-TERM, HIGH FREQUENCY SAMPLING TECHNIQUES. THE SHELLFISH AQUACULTURE GENETICS AND BREEDING PROJECT WILL TRAIN GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND IMPROVE EASTERN OYSTER'S DISEASE

THIS PROJECT, CALLED ENERGY EFFICIENT FISHERIES (EEF), WILL COMBINE EXPERTISE FROM THE MASSACHUSETTS COMMERCIAL FISHING AND SEAFOOD INDUSTRIES WITH EXPERTISE FROM THE ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND RENEWABLE TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRIES TO DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE SET OF PATHWAYS TOWARDS REDUCTION OF GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS FROM THE HARVEST, PROCESSING, AND SALE OF SEAFOOD BY MASSACHUSETTS-BASED FISHERMEN AND BUSINESSES. EEF WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A SERIES OF PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS TO CHART A COURSE FOR EMISSIONS REDUCTIONS AND THE ADOPTION OF NEXT-GENERATION ENERGY EFFICIENCY TECHNOLOGIES BY MASSACHUSETTS FISHING VESSELS, SEAFOOD BUSINESSES, AND FISHING PORTS. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL POSITION MASSACHUSETTS TO CONTINUE ITS CLIMATE LEADERSHIP BY PILOTING AND IMPLEMENTING SAFE, COST-EFFECTIVE, PROVEN APPROACHES DESIGNED FOR AND BY FISHERIES AND SEAFOOD STAKEHOLDERS THEMSELVES.

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO EXPAND BUFFALO NIAGARA WATERKEEPER'S (BNW) DECADES LONG WATER QUALITY AND ECOSYSTEM MONITORING PROJECT TO ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING AND PUBLIC AWARENESS OF WESTERN NEW YORK'S (WNY) LAKE ERIE COASTLINE AND NEARSHORE ENVIRONMENTS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THROUGH THIS PROJECT, BNW WILL UNDERTAKE A DETAILED LITERATURE REVIEW OF DATA AND RESEARCH FOCUSED ON THE EASTERN BASIN OF LAKE ERIE WATER QUALITY. THE LITERATURE REVIEW WILL INFORM OPPORTUNITIES TO EXPAND AND DEVELOP A MORE ROBUST WATER QUALITY AND ECOSYSTEM MONITORING PROGRAM THROUGH ADDITIONAL SITES. COUPLED WITH THE ADDITIONAL WATER QUALITY DATA, BNW WILL DEVELOP A SHORELINE VISUAL ASSESSMENT TOOL TO IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR INCREASED COASTAL RESILIENCE EFFORTS. DATA GATHERED THROUGH OUR WATER QUALITY MONITORING PROGRAM AND VISUAL SHORELINE ASSESSMENTS WILL GUIDE OUR COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND VOLUNTEER EFFORTS THROUGH EVENTS AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING. IN ORDER TO FURTHER EXPAND IN THE INDUSTRY OF NATIONAL DEFENSE RESEARCH, WHOI IS CONSTRUCTING A FACILITY FOCUSED ON SECURE RESEARCH, IN MULTIPLE CAPACITIES, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH VARIOUS AGENCIES. THE SECURE UNDERWATER RESEARCH FACILITY (SURF) WILL PROVIDE SECURE OPEN AND/OR COMPARTMENTALIZED LABORATORIES, WORK ROOMS, AND MEETING SPACES. THE FACILITY IS DESIGNED TO MEET THE REQUIREMENTS TO OBTAIN APPROVAL BY COGNIZANT AGENCIES WITH JURISDICTION OVER SUCH FACILITIES AND APPROVAL AUTHORITY AT THE LEVEL OF OPEN STORAGE SECRET AS A BASELINE RATING. SURF WILL ALLOW WHOI RESEARCHERS, INDUSTRY PARTNERS, SMALL BUSINESS AND START-UPS SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASED OPPORTUNITIES FOR COLLABORATION, THEREBY SHORTENING THE TIME BETWEEN INNOVATION AND DELIVERY OF NEW CAPABILITIES. THIS PROJECT SCOPE SHALL BE DEVELOPED AND CONSTRUCTED TO ALLOW FOR FUTURE GROWTH. TOTAL BUILDOUT COST OF THE FACILITY IS ESTIMATED TO BE $2.2M WITH REMAINING FUNDS PROVIDED BY WHOI.

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR DOWNEAST INSTITUTE'S (DEI) MARINE RESEARCH WHICH IS PRIMARILY AIMED AT ENHANCING FISHERIES PRODUCTION THROUGH SUSTAINING WILD SHELLFISH HARVESTS AND DEVELOPING NEW SHELLFISH AQUACULTURE OPPORTUNITIES. THE EQUIPMENT AND ACTIVITIES FUNDED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF DEI'S RESEARCH HATCHERY AND SEAWATER LABORATORIES, AS WELL AS IMPROVE EFFICIENCY AND SAFETY.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: ACTIVITIES INVOLVE SUPPORTING EXISTING STAFF AND PURCHASING OR LEASING INFRASTRUCTURE WHICH WILL INCREASE DEI'S ABILITY TO CONDUCT RESEARCH ON THE CELLULAR LEVEL; IMPROVE SAFETY AND CAPABILITIES OF RESEARCH VESSELS AND VEHICLES; IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS IN THE HATCHERY BUILDING; AND INCREASE DIVERSITY AND UTILITY OF SEA WATER LABS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE OUTCOME OF THESE INVESTMENTS WILL BE INCREASED CAPACITY AND FUNCTION AT DEI, A WORLD-CLASS MARINE RESEARCH FACILITY WITH A COMMERCIAL SCALE EXPERIMENTAL SHELLFISH HATC

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPLEMENT THE CONNECTICUT KELP INNOVATION CENTER, WHICH WILL ADDRESS CRITICAL BARRIERS THAT HAMPER GROWTH OF SEAWEED CULTIVATION IN CONNECTICUT, CREATING WORKING WATERFRONT JOBS THAT HAVE A CLIMATE POSITIVE IMPACT.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE CENTER WILL ADDRESS THESE BARRIERS BY INCREASING LOCAL FARMER-OPERATED KELP SEED PRODUCTION CAPACITY, HELPING FARMERS SCALE OPERATIONS, DEVELOPING A SHARED-USE MOBILE PLATFORM FOR HARVEST, PRIMARY PROCESSING, AND STABILIZATION, AND EXPANDING COLD STORAGE CAPACITY.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT ANNUAL KELP SEED PRODUCTION CAPACITY IN CONNECTICUT WILL TRIPLE TO 225,000 FEET WHICH CAN YIELD UP TO 1.8 MILLION POUNDS OF WET HARVEST, BY 2027, 7 CONNECTICUT KELP FARMERS WILL INCREASE PRODUCTION BY 300,000 - 500,000 LBS AND 3 SHELLFISH FARMERS WILL DIVERSIFY OPERATIONS TO INCLUDE KELP; AND CONNECTICUT FARMERS WILL EXPAND PRODUCTION, REDUCE COSTS, AND CAPTURE MORE OF THE KEL

THE GLC WILL UTILIZE THIS ADDITIONAL EXPERTISE/CAPACITY TO ENSURE THE STATES AND THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT ARE COORDINATED AND COMMUNICATING ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF IMPORTANT FEDERAL AND REGIONAL PROGRAMS RELATED TO THE GREAT LAKES BASIN, INCLUDING INVESTMENTS MADE UNDER THE INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT AND JOBS ACT AND INFLATION REDUCTION ACT.  THE GLC WILL EXPAND ITS WORK ON ACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN ITS NEW STRATEGIC PLAN, UTILIZING THE GLC'S STRENGTHS AND SERVICES OF FACILITATION AND CONSENSUS-BUILDING AND INFORMATION MANAGEMENT AND DELIVERY. THIS WILL INCLUDE FACILITATING REGIONAL MEETINGS TO CONVENE EXPERTS FROM STATE, FEDERAL, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT ENTITIES TO COORDINATE ACTIONS, AND IMPLEMENT PLANS RELATED TO RESTORATION, INFRASTRUCTURE, AND CLIMATE RESILIENCE. THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS WILL PROVIDE STATE OF THE ART SUBSEASONAL TO MULTIYEAR FORECASTS FOR ALASKA AND THE ARCTIC. THE PROPOSED WORK INCLUDES 1) ADVANCE SUPPORT FOR S2S FORECASTS THROUGH COMMUNITY-BASED OBSERVATIONS; 2) CLIMATE ANALOG DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION TO S2S OUTLOOKS FOR STORMINESS; 3) WILDLAND FIRE MODELING AND PREDICTION; 4) FORECASTING WINTER RAIN EVENTS; AND 5) EXAMINING EXTREME ATMOSPHERIC VARIABILITY AND IMPACTS IN THE CHUKCHI SEA. THE PROJECT LEVERAGES SEVERAL TRUSTED REGIONAL PARTNERS TO SUPPORT THIS WORK, INCLUDING THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE (NWS) ARCTIC TESTBED, ALASKA ARCTIC OBSERVATORY AND KNOWLEDGE HUB (AAOKH), NOAA-FUNDED CLIMATE ADAPTATION PARTNERSHIP/REGIONALLY INTEGRATED SCIENCES AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAM IN ALASKA (ALASKA CENTER FOR CLIMATE ASSESSMENT AND POLICY, ACCAP), AND ALASKA FIRE SCIENCE CONSORTIUM (AFSC).

PURPOSE: TO DEVELOP AND PRIORITIZE SCIENCE-BASED, COMMUNITY-INFORMED RESILIENCE IN AT LEAST FIVE LOUISIANA COMMUNITIES TO ENHANCE AND EXPAND CLIMATE RESILIENCE EQUITABLY.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: CONVENING AND COORDINATING WITH PRACTITIONERS, COMMUNITIES, AND OTHER PARTNERS WORKING TO BE MORE RESILIENT; IMPROVING MULTIDIRECTIONAL KNOWLEDGE SHARING AROUND THE RISKS, NEEDS, AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR IMPROVING COASTAL CLIMATE RESILIENCE IN UNDERSERVED, FRONTLINE COMMUNITIES; CONDUCTING SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH FOCUSED ON GAINING A GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF THE POLICIES, PROCESSES, AND SYSTEMIC BARRIERS TO PURSUING RESILIENCE AND POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS; AND INCREASING RESILIENCE ACTION THROUGH ENSURING THAT A GREATER NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES ARE ABLE TO PURSUE CLIMATE RESILIENCE PLANNING AND ACTIVITIES.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: GREATER CONFIDENCE AMONG COASTAL RESIDENTS ON THEIR UNDERSTANDING OF AND ABILITY TO ADDRESS THESE TOPICS; GREATER UNDERSTANDING BY RESEARCHERS AND FUNDERS AB

THE PROPOSAL SEEKS TO ENHANCE MONITORING, DATA VISUALIZATION, ONLINE COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS, AND MAP-BASED FLOOD FORECAST SYSTEMS. THIS WILL LESSEN THE IMPACTS OF FUTURE FLOODS BY PROTECTING PROPERTY AND LIVES AND REDUCING RECOVERY COSTS FROM FUTURE FLOODS. CONDUCTING A HYDROLOGIC ASSESSMENT FOR TWO NEWLY FORMED WATERSHED MANAGEMENT AUTHORITIES, THE MAQUOKETA RIVER AND LOWER CEDAR RIVER WATERSHEDS, WILL IDENTIFY AND COMMUNICATE AREAS VULNERABLE TO FLOODING. THE SECOND PROPOSED ACTIVITY INCLUDES DEPLOYING ONE HYDROLOGIC WEATHER STATION IN CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS 1 AND 2 THAT CURRENTLY DO NOT HOST A MONITORING STATION. THE ESTIMATED FUNDING AMOUNT IS $1,000,000. THIS ACTION IS NON-CONTROVERSIAL.

THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE AS A PILOT FOR HOW TO INTEGRATE, SHARE, AND USE ACCURATE, REAL TIME PRECIPITATION DATA WHILE INFORMING THE DEVELOPMENT OF A STATE-WIDE NETWORK, FUTURE FLOOD RISK MODELS, AND A REGIONAL EARLY WARNING SYSTEM IN VIRGINIA. BY UPDATING AND ADDING A NEW BASE STATION AND GAGES, THIS STUDY WILL COMPUTE A SUITE OF HYDROLOGIC METRICS TO CHARACTERIZE THE FLOW REGIME, INVESTIGATE MULTI-DECADAL TRENDS IN THOSE METRICS, AND COMPARE METRICS AT FOUR MILE RUN TO OTHER MONITORED STREAMS IN THE REGION WHERE SIMILAR ANALYSES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED.

THE FUNDING WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT PHASE TWO OF CONSTRUCTION OF THE FERRIS STATE UNIVERSITY CENTER FOR VIRTUAL LEARNING, SPECIFICALLY TOWARD EQUIPPING AND INSTALLING THE TECHNOLOGY AND ISOLATED NETWORK CAPACITY ESSENTIAL TO MAXIMIZE THE POTENTIAL OF THE FACILITY.

THIS STUDY WILL ADVANCE THE UNDERSTANDING OF COMPOUND FLOODING IN NEW YORK CITY RESULTING FROM SEA LEVEL RISE, MORE INTENSE PRECIPITATION, AND HIGHER GROUNDWATER TABLES.  THIS WILL HELP IN THE PREPARATION FOR COMPOUND FLOODING BY STUDYING THE PROJECTED EFFECTS OF TIDAL CYCLES UNDER HIGHER SEA LEVELS UPON TIDE GATES, AND PLANNING ADAPTATION STRATEGIES TO MINIMIZE OR AVOID THE CONSEQUENCES OF SEA LEVEL RISE UPON THE SEWER SYSTEM.

OUR COASTAL COMMUNITIES HAVE ALWAYS FACED FLOODING EVENTS, MINOR TO MAJOR, BUT THESE ARE PROJECTED TO INCREASE BECAUSE OF WARMING OF THE EARTH'S SURFACE TEMPERATURE AND BECAUSE OF INCREASING SEA LEVELS BECAUSE OF THE OCEAN'S INCREASING TEMPERATURE AND THE MELTING OF THE EARTH'S ICE SHEETS. THE INCREASING SURFACE TEMPERATURE LEADS TO AN ATMOSPHERE THAT CAN HOLD MORE WATER, AND THIS IN TURN MEANS THAT THERE IS A GREATER POTENTIAL FOR UNEXPECTEDLY HIGH RAINFALL RATES. WHY DOES IT MATTER THAT THE AIR CAN HOLD MORE WATER? IT'S BECAUSE OUR STORM WATER SYSTEMS WERE DESIGNED TO CARRY A CERTAIN AMOUNT OF WATER PER HOUR OFF OF OUR STREETS AND CAN BE OVERWHELMED IF THE AMOUNT OF RAIN FALLING IN AN HOUR INCREASES DUE TO A WARMER ATMOSPHERE.  THIS PROBLEM IS EXASPERATED IF THE SEA LEVEL IS ALSO RISING BECAUSE OF A WARMING OCEAN AND ICE MELT. IN MOST PLACES OUR STORM WATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM WORKS BY ALLOWING WATER TO RUN DOWNHILL, MEANING DOWN TO SEA LEVEL, BUT IF THE SEA LEVEL IS HIGHER THE EFFICIE

THIS NOAA-FUNDED WORK WILL SUPPORT SEVERAL ELEMENTS OF A LAKE-WIDE MONITORING NETWORK TO COLLECT AND RECORD LAKE CHAMPLAIN ENVIRONMENTAL DATA IN REAL-TIME AND TO EXPLORE AND DEVELOP MONITORING PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS NEW ISSUES. THE WORK WILL SUPPORT FOUR PRIMARY MONITORING NEEDS FOR LAKE CHAMPLAIN WITH FY22 FUNDS:  1) IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANTS OF CONCERN IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN THROUGH A LITERATURE REVIEW, TARGETED SAMPLING, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A FUTURE MONITORING PROGRAM FRAMEWORK WILL INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND DIRECT RESOURCES TOWARD ADDRESSING SOURCES AND EFFECTS OF THESE CONTAMINANTS.  2) CYANOTOXIN TESTING FOR RECREATIONAL WATER SAMPLES WILL IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF PUBLIC HEALTH RISKS AND IMPROVE OUR COMMUNICATION ON CYANOBACTERIA BLOOMS TO LAKE USERS AND STAKEHOLDERS.  3) IN-SITU REAL-TIME MONITORING INSTRUMENTATION WILL INCREASE THE DATA RESOLUTION FOR ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITION AND TREND ANALYSIS AND PROVIDE USEFUL COMPARISONS OF LAKE REGIONS

THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT EDUCATION AND STEM COMMUNITY OUTREACH IN COASTAL RESILIENCE. THIS FUNDING WILL BE USED TO PURCHASE SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS FOR REMOTE SENSING OF SOUTHERN NEW JERSEY'S COASTAL ENVIRONMENT AND MAPPING OF THE BEACHES, BARRIER ISLANDS AND BACK BAY MARSHES TO PROVIDE HIGH-LEVEL STUDENT TRAINING IN COASTAL RESILIENCE. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE STUDENTS AT STOCKTON UNIVERSITY ENROLLED IN UNDERGRADUATE MARINE AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE AND GRADUATE COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO PROVIDE AUTHENTIC STEM FIELD EXPERIENCES FOR MIDDLE- AND HIGH-SCHOOL STUDENTS IN ATLANTIC CITY AND SURROUNDING UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, OFFERING A VITAL INTRODUCTION TO EMPLOYMENT AND HIGHER EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES REGARDING THE UNITED STATES' GROWING BLUE ECONOMY AND PROMOTE AWARENESS OF JOB OPPORTUNITIES IN THE DEVELOPING OFFSHORE WIND ENERGY ECONOMY CENTERED AROUND SOUTHERN NEW JERSEY.

WATERFRONT ALLIANCE WILL LEAD DEVELOPMENT OF A CLIMATE RESILIENCE PLAN FOR FLUSHING MEADOWS CORONA PARK LOCATED IN QUEENS, NEW YORK CITY. FLUSHING MEADOWS CORONA PARK IS QUEENS' SIGNATURE LOCAL AND DESTINATION PARK, SERVING SEVERAL COMMUNITIES WITH HIGH SOCIAL VULNERABILITY ACTS AS A VITAL SPACE FOR CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE, RECREATION, REFUSE FROM URBAN HEAT. HOWEVER, THE PARK IS FACING TREMENDOUS CHALLENGES DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, INCLUDING FLOODING, SEA LEVEL RISE, STORM SURGES. THE CLIMATE RESILIENCE PLAN WILL RESULT IN A SET OF PROJECT DESIGNS AND RECOMMENDATIONS TO REDUCE FLOODING AND ADAPT THE PARK FOR FUTURE CLIMATE CHALLENGES. THROUGHOUT THE PROCESS, THE GOAL IS TO BUILD COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION AND CLIMATE AWARENESS WITH A FOCUS ON FLUSHING MEADOWS CORONA PARK, AND TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL RESILIENCY PROJECTS FOR FUTURE INVESTIGATION AND DEVELOPMENT.

VDATUM IS A SOFTWARE TOOL DESIGNED TO VERTICALLY TRANSFORM GEOSPATIAL DATA AMONG A VARIETY OF TIDAL, ORTHOMETRIC AND ELLIPSOIDAL VERTICAL DATUMS - ALLOWING USERS TO CONVERT THEIR DATA FROM DIFFERENT HORIZONTAL/VERTICAL REFERENCE FRAMES INTO A COMMON AND CONSISTENT SYSTEM, THEREBY ENABLING THE FUSION OF DIVERSE GEOSPATIAL DATA AND ALIGNMENT RELATIVE TO DESIRED REFERENCE LEVELS.   COMPLETION OF STATEWIDE VDATUM IS A TOP PRIORITY IN THE ALASKA COASTAL MAPPING STRATEGY BECAUSE IT NOT ONLY ENABLES OTHER MAPPING ACTIVITIES, BUT ALSO UN-LOCKS THE ABILITY TO DEVELOP TOOLS, SERVICES, AND CAPABILITIES NOT YET AVAILABLE IN ALASKA BUT AVAILABLE TO OTHER PARTS OF THE UNITED STATES, SUCH AS SEA LEVEL RISE VIEWERS THAT ARE CRITICAL TO INFORMED COMMUNITY PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT. VDATUM PROVIDES READY ACCESS TO THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE LAND AND SEA, THEREBY ENHANCING THE ACCURATE COLLECTION AND USE OF GEOSPATIAL DATA AT THE COAST IN APPLICATIONS LIKE FLOOD AND SEA LEVEL INUNDATION MAPPING, ENGIN

ST. MARY'S RIVER WATERSHED ASSOCIATION, INC. (SMRWA) IS RECEIVING $185,000 FOR A COMMUNITY PROJECT TO SUPPORT OYSTER RESTORATION IN THE ST. MARY'S SHELLFISH SANCTUARY. THE PROJECT PERIOD IS FROM SEPTEMBER 1, 2023 TO AUGUST 31, 2025. FOR THIS PROJECT, SMRWA WILL USE THE FUNDING TO WORK WITH STATE AND ACADEMIC PARTNERS TO DEVELOP RESEARCH PLANS, IMPLEMENT SMALL-SCALE PILOT STUDIES AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES, AND PURCHASE SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT INCLUDING THE ACQUISITION OF A 22' VESSEL THAT WILL SUPPORT FUTURE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RESEARCH AND MONITORING PLANS. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WOULD 1) DEVELOP A STUDY TO EVALUATE NATURAL DISEASE RESISTANCE WITHIN AND OUTSIDE THE ST. MARY'S RIVER OYSTER SANCTUARY AND CONDUCT LIMITED OYSTER DISEASE TESTING 2) GATHER WATER QUALITY DATA AND PLAN FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN OYSTER LARVAL DISPERSAL MODEL FOR A PORTION OF THE ST. MARY'S RIVER AND 3) DEVELOP AND PILOT A STUDY OF THE ESSENTIAL NATURAL ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS PROVIDED BY THE ST. MARY'S RIVER O

UPPER COLUMBIA UNITED TRIBES' PHASE 2 IMPLEMENTATION PLAN GOALS RELATED TO THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF INTERIM PASSAGE SOLUTIONS, AND THE GATHERING OF DATA TO, DETERMINE THE NEED, TYPE, AND COSTS OF PERMANENT FISH PASSAGE SYSTEMS. THE EXPECTED MEASURABLE BENEFIT IS THE OPENING UP OF MORE THAN 1,000 MILES OF ANADROMOUS SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT THAT IS CURRENTLY BLOCKED BY FIVE HIGH-HEAD DAMS ON THE COLUMBIA AND SPOKANE RIVERS. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE DESIGN OF FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES AT SEVERAL OF THESE DAMS, BRINGING THE UCUT TRIBES CLOSER TO A LONG-TERM SOLUTION FOR FISH PASSAGE.

THE COQUILLE INDIAN TRIBE, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW), HAVE EMBARKED ON A MULTI-FACETED, ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT APPROACH TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS KEY IN-BASIN LIMITING FACTORS BELIEVED TO BE DEPRESSING THE FALL CHINOOK POPULATION VIABILITY AND ABUNDANCE. PILLARS OF THE COQUILLE RIVER SALMON CONSERVATION PROJECT (CRSCP) INCLUDE: ENSURING BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE, DATA AND INFORMATION AND TRIBAL TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE ARE INFORMING MANAGEMENT PLANS AND IMPLEMENTATION ACTIONS; RESTORING AND PROTECTING CHINOOK HABITAT IN THE COQUILLE RIVER; AND IMPROVING EXISTING HATCHERY INFRASTRUCTURE AND OPERATIONS.

THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE (UMCES) IS RECEIVING $960,000 TO SUPPORT A COMMUNITY PROJECT FOCUSED ON RESEARCH AND RESTORATION OF OYSTERS IN CHESAPEAKE BAY. UMCES SCIENTISTS WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH AND EVALUATION OF OYSTER RELATED RESTORATION PROJECTS INCLUDING: 1) TRANSPORT AND FATE OF OYSTER LARVAE FROM SANCTUARIES AND PUBLIC BARS; AND 2) THE IMPACTS OF OYSTER RESTORATION ON KEY CHESAPEAKE BAY SPECIES; AND 3) EVALUATING THE BEST LOCATIONS FOR OYSTER RESTORATION AND AQUACULTURE THAT MAXIMIZES ECOSYSTEMS SERVICES. THESE RESEARCH RESULTS CAN BE APPLIED WITHIN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY, PARTICULARLY TO STATE AND FEDERALLY FUNDED RESTORATION SITES SUCH AS SANCTUARIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE ASSOCIATED WITH POPLAR AND MID-BAY ISLANDS THUS ENHANCING THE BENEFICIAL USE OF DREDGE MATERIAL. SCIENTIFIC INTEGRATION AND COMMUNICATION SESSIONS WILL BE HELP ANNUALLY AS WELL AS AN OYSTER SYMPOSIUM IN YEAR 3 OF THIS PROJECT.

SAVE THE BAY WILL BE AWARDED $1,660,000 TO SUPPORT A FOUR YEAR COMMUNITY PROJECT THAT IS INTENDED TO LEVERAGE ITS 25 YEARS OF HABITAT RESTORATION AND ADVOCACY EXPERIENCE BY IDENTIFYING, DEVELOPING, AND IMPLEMENTING HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS THROUGHOUT RHODE ISLAND PORTIONS OF THE NARRAGANSETT BAY WATERSHED. THIS FUNDING WILL BE USED TO ASSESS AND IMPLEMENT PREVIOUSLY-IDENTIFIED HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AND PRIORITIES. THESE INCLUDE PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS STREAM CONNECTIVITY, SALT MARSH RESTORATION, AND COASTAL RESILIENCE. ADDITIONALLY, THESE FUNDS WILL SUPPORT COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT THROUGH LEVERAGING EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS AS WELL AS CONDUCTING OUTREACH EVENTS FOCUSING ON ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE EFFORTS AND COMMUNITIES. UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON-TACOMA CENTER OF URBAN WATERS: PROTECTING SALMON FROM TOXIC CHEMICALS " RESEARCHERS WILL EVALUATE THE IMPACTS OF ROADWAY RUNOFF AND ASSOCIATED TIRE RUBBER CHEMICALS ON SALMON HEALTH.  THE CENTER FOR URBAN WATERS ENVIRONMENTAL MASS SPECTROMETRY RESEARCH LABORATORIES WILL ACQUIRE A NEW STATE-OF THE-ART, SENSITIVE SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT TO BETTER MEASURE KEY CHEMICALS IN ROADWAY RUNOFF AS THEY DEVELOP ADVANCED METHODS TO ADDRESS COMPELLING DATA GAPS AROUND THE WATER QUALITY DEGRADATION ARISING FROM TIRE RUBBER CHEMICALS AND ROADWAY POLLUTION. RESEARCHERS WILL ADDRESS HOW TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE OCCURRENCE AND MANAGEMENT OF ROADWAY-DERIVED CONTAINMENTS IN ROADWAY RUNOFF IN WASHINGTON STATE.

THE NATURE CONSERVANCY IN FLORIDA WILL LAUNCH A PILOT PROJECT TO INVESTIGATE MODERNIZING RECREATIONAL CATCH DATA IN THE US SOUTHEAST ATLANTIC. THE PROJECT WILL ENCOURAGE AND INCENTIVIZE RECREATIONAL CAPTAINS AND ANGLERS TO REPORT CATCH INFORMATION FOR DEEPWATER SPECIES THROUGH PHONE-BASED 'APPS.' THE NATURE CONSERVANCY WILL ENGAGE WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, KEY ANGLER GROUPS AND INDIVIDUALS TO FURTHER UNDERSTAND KNOWN CHALLENGES WITH ELECTRONIC REPORTING. THE GOAL IS TO DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE TYPE OF DATA (PERFORMANCE STANDARDS) THAT SHOULD BE COLLECTED ON MULTIPLE APPS TO MAXIMIZE UTILITY FOR MANAGEMENT. FURTHER STEPS TO ENCOURAGE PARTICIPATION INCLUDE A SERIES OF WORKSHOPS, PUBLISHED MATERIALS, AND OUTREACH VIA TARGETED MEDIA OUTLETS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO APPLY GLIDERS TO THE TASK OF COLLECTING ENVIRONMENTAL AND FISHERIES DATA THAT WILL HELP ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES WITHIN ALASKAN FISHERIES AND ULTIMATELY SUPPORT THEIR SUSTAINABILITY. WE PROPOSE TO DEPLOY SLOCUM GLIDERS IN THE GULF OF ALASKA AND THE BEING SEA IN AN EFFORT TO DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN REPEAT OBSERVATION TRACK LINES. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN ALL SEASONS, BUT WITH PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON WINTER AND SPRING WHEN LIMITED NUMBERS OF VESSEL-BASED SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED AND THE MARINE ECOSYSTEM IS TRANSITIONING INTO THE SPRING BLOOM. THIS PROJECT BUILDS ON PAST INVESTMENTS IN SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT AND HARDWARE UPGRADES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS SLOCUM GLIDER FLEET. WE WILL WORK WITH THE ALEUT COMMUNITY OF ST. PAUL ISLAND TO ASSESS FEASIBILITY OF OPERATING GLIDER SURVEYS IN THE MIDDLE OF THE BERING SEA.

THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH AND DIAGNOSTIC ACTIVITIES FOCUSED ON IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF AQUATIC ANIMALS, AND THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT, IN THE GULF OF MEXICO, PARTICULARLY IN THE MISSISSIPPI SOUND. THIS WILL ENHANCE SOUTH MISSISSIPPI BY PROTECTING OUR COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES AND SUPPORTING THE GROWTH OF MARINE AQUACULTURE. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO ESTABLISH THE MS GULF COAST AQUATIC HEALTH LABORATORY IN ORDER TO CONDUCT RESEARCH AND DIAGNOSTIC ACTIVITIES FOCUSED ON IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF AQUATIC ANIMALS AND THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT IN THE GULF OF MEXICO.

THE ALEUT COMMUNITY OF ST. PAUL ISLAND IS A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED TRIBE FROM THE PRIBILOF ISLANDS IN THE CENTRAL BERING SEA. BEYOND SERVING THE NEEDS OF THEIR OWN TRIBAL MEMBERS, IT IS A STATEWIDE LEADER IN ASSISTING OTHER TRIBES WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF THEIR ENVIRONMENTAL PROGRAMS. IT ESTABLISHED THE INDIGENOUS SENTINELS NETWORK, AS A PLATFORM FOR TRIBES DOCUMENT ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE AND FILL CRITICAL KNOWLEDGE GAPS. THIS NETWORK HAS OPERATED FOR 18 YEARS AS AN ONLINE DATABASE TOOL FOR NON-SCIENTISTS IN REMOTE LOCATIONS TO SYSTEMATICALLY RECORD AND SHARE ENVIRONMENTAL AND BIOLOGICAL DATA IN A STANDARDIZED WAY. BUILDING FROM THE SUCCESSFUL NETWORK PLATFORM AND ITS CATALOG OF SMARTPHONE APPS, SKIPPER SCIENCE WILL HELP OUR STATE'S FISHERMEN DELIVER MUCH-NEEDED INFORMATION FROM REMOTE MARINE LOCATIONS TO TRACK ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES, COASTAL HAZARDS, FISHERIES, AND SPECIES OF CONCERN. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF THE SEAFOOD INDUSTRY TO CHALLENGES ARISING FROM CLIMATE CHANGE AND TO IMPROVE U.S. FOOD SECURITY. AN INTERDISCIPLINARY GROUP OF SCIENTISTS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND WILL WORK WITH THE INDUSTRY AND SCIENTISTS FROM OTHER INSTITUTIONS TO ACCELERATE SELECTIVE BREEDING EFFORTS OF AGRICULTURALLY IMPORTANT SEAFOOD SPECIES (E.G. OYSTERS, CLAMS) THROUGH THE APPLICATION OF ADVANCED TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS (EPI)GENOMIC DESIGN, SENSOR DEVELOPMENT, AND SMART ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP THE RESOURCES NECESSARY FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THESE APPROACHES TO AQUACULTURE RESILIENCE. IMPACTS INCLUDE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE EFFECT OF ENVIRONMENT ON PERFORMANCE, AND RAPID RESPONSE TO ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE AND THE PRESENCE OF STRESSORS AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS THAT MAY LEAD TO DECREASES IN PRODUCTION.

THE DATA GATHERING INITIATIVE (DGI) SEEKS TO FACILITATE PERMIT APPLICATION AND REVIEW PROCESSES, THUS SPEEDING INFRASTRUCTURE CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE AT WATERFRONT FACILITIES. IT INVOLVES IDENTIFYING, ASSEMBLING, VALIDATING, SHARING, AND UTILIZING EMPIRICAL DATA NEEDED FOR PERMITTING, SUCH AS INFORMATION ON ENDANGERED SPECIES ACTIVITIES AND CRITICAL HABITATS. IT WILL COLLECT COMPREHENSIVE DATA, STORE OR LINK TO IT IN AN EASILY ACCESSIBLE, CENTRALIZED DATABASE, AND PROVIDE IT TO STAKEHOLDERS, PROMOTING EFFICIENT AND CONSISTENT PERMIT APPLICATION AND REVIEW PROCESSES. POTENTIAL SYSTEM USERS INCLUDE INDUSTRY, ACADEMIA, ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND THE PUBLIC.

THE PEOPLE OF THE YUKON RIVER RELY HEAVILY ON THE WATERSHED'S NATURAL RESOURCES TO FEED THEIR FAMILIES AND SUPPORT THEIR CULTURE. ANNUAL CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON HARVEST IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE LIVELIHOOD OF THE 76 SMALL, RURAL VILLAGES SCATTERED AROUND THE ~330,000 SQUARE MILE WATERSHED. SINCE 1997, CHINOOK SALMON RUNS AND HARVEST HAVE DECLINED. IN RECENT YEARS, BOTH CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON RUNS FAILED COMPLETELY WITH DEVASTATING CONSEQUENCES TO YUKON RIVER WATERSHED PEOPLE, FAMILIES, COMMUNITY AND CULTURE. SIGNIFICANT HABITAT ALTERATION HAS OCCURRED THROUGHOUT PORTIONS OF THE YUKON RIVER WATERSHED IN ALASKA AND CANADA THAT COULD BE IMPACTING SALMON RECRUITMENT, YET NO COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF THESE ALTERATIONS AND THEIR POTENTIAL IMPACT TO WILD SALMON RUNS HAS BEEN COMPLETED. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO CONDUCT A FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR AN ON-WATER CENTER OF EXCELLENCE FOR TRANSFORMATIVE COASTAL TEACHING, RESEARCH AND SERVICE AT THE URI NARRAGANSETT BAY CAMPUS (NBC) TO DEEPEN UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THE CHANGING CLIMATE AFFECTS RELIANCE ON OCEANS AND COASTS (GOODS, SERVICES, TRANSPORT AND TOURISM). TASKS WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPING A SCOPING STUDY THROUGH HIRING LOCAL SURVEYORS, ENGINEERS, COASTAL PLANNERS, AND CONTRACTORS TO DEVELOP SHOVEL-READY PLANS FOR AN ON-WATER FACILITY WHICH WILL INCLUDE CLASSROOM SPACES, SUPPORT STAFF OFFICES, AND A BOAT MAINTENANCE SHOP TO SUPPORT AND GROW URI'S FLEET OF SMALL VESSELS (CURRENTLY FIVE BOATS).

WORCESTER STATE UNIVERSITY (WSU) WILL RECRUIT 20 UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT PARTICIPANTS, EACH FALL SEMESTER (2022 AND 2023) WHO WILL BE STUDENTS ENTERING WORCESTER STATE UNIVERSITY FROM FIRST GENERATION, UNDERREPRESENTED AND ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES. THE ANNUAL COHORT OF 15 STUDENT PARTICIPANTS WILL BE IMMERSED IN AN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING MODEL CONSISTING OF: (I) A 4-CREDIT COURSE IN CLIMATE SCIENCE RESEARCH; (II) MATH TUTORING AND MENTORING; (III) OUTREACH TO HIGH SCHOOLS; AND, (IV) HANDS-ON LABORATORY WITH FIELD SAMPLING ACTIVITIES. EACH STUDENT WILL BE EXPOSED TO MENTORING, MATH TUTORING, A RESIDENTIAL 6-WEEK SUMMER RESEARCH PROGRAM, AND DELIVER OUTREACH PRESENTATIONS TO THEIR HIGH SCHOOLS TO DEMONSTRATE KNOWLEDGE GAINED ABOUT THE REGIONAL IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. WITH THIS PROJECT, WSU AIMS TO DEVELOP THE CAPACITY AND EXECUTE A CROSS-DISCIPLINE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE LAB SCIENCE CLASS DEDICATED TO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT LEARNING AND CLIMATE SCIENCE RESEARCH STRENGTHENING

THE NURTURE NATURE CENTER'S PROJECT TITLED "CREATE RESILIENCE RESEARCH AND COMMUNITY LEARNING HUB'" WILL START A NEW INITIATIVE IN EASTON, PA TO EXPAND THE CAPACITY, RESOURCES, AND EDUCATIONAL AND ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE TO LOCAL COMMUNITIES IN THE LEHIGH VALLEY. THE CREATE HUB WILL PROVIDE THE KNOWLEDGE, RESOURCES, AND CONNECTIONS SO THAT COMMUNITIES CAN MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT THE CHALLENGES THEY FACE AND TURN THOSE CHALLENGES INTO OPPORTUNITIES TO IMPROVE THEIR LOCAL ENVIRONMENT AND THEIR ABILITY TO ADAPT AND PREPARE. SPECIFICALLY, THE HUB WILL CONNECT COMMUNITIES TO EXPERTS AND NOAA RESOURCES AND ASSETS THAT WILL ALLOW THEM TO CREATE EFFECTIVE PLANS RELATED TO RESILIENCY, VULNERABILITY, AND ADAPTATION, WHILE PROVIDING TEMPLATES THAT ENABLE COMMUNITIES TO STRATEGIZE ABOUT, MAP, AND UNDERSTAND THEIR ASSETS AND HOW TO ENGAGE THOSE ASSETS TO PREPARE FOR THE CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES AHEAD.

THE SAVE THE BAY'S PROJECT TITLED "WHAT IS MY PLACE IN THE WATERSHED? A MWEE PROGRAM OF EXCELLENCE FOR 4TH GRADERS IN WARWICK, RI" WILL IMPLEMENT A BACKYARD B-WET MODEL PROGRAM INTEGRATING MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATION EXPERIENCES INTO DISTRICT-WIDE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL SCIENCE CURRICULUM AND TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, SAVE THE BAY WILL ANNUALLY ENGAGE APPROXIMATELY 700 STUDENTS AND 14-30 SCIENCE TEACHERS FROM ALL PUBLIC ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS IN WARWICK, RI. STUDENTS AND TEACHERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN AUTHENTIC INVESTIGATION AND STEWARDSHIP OPPORTUNITIES IN THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITY AND ALONG THE COAST OF NARRAGANSETT BAY, ELEVATING THEIR ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND STEWARDSHIP BEHAVIOR.

THE TOWN OF HEMPSTEAD'S PROJECT (AWARD #NA22SEC4690003) TITLED "MARINE NATURE STUDY AREA EDUCATIONAL DISPLAYS" WILL DESIGN AND INSTALL A NEW EXHIBIT AND INTERACTIVE DISPLAYS AT THE NEW MARINE NATURE STUDY AREA (MNSA) FACILITY IN OCEANSIDE, NY. THE TOWN OF HEMPSTEAD WILL POPULATE THE NEW STRUCTURE WITH EDUCATIONAL TOOLS, INTUITIVE TOUCH INTERFACES, COLORFUL DISPLAYS, AND EXHIBITS TO MAKE THIS NEW FACILITY A SPECTACULAR RESOURCE TO THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AND BEYOND. THE NEW INTERPRETIVE CENTER WILL AIM TO CAPTURE THE IMAGINATION OF THE VISITORS AND STUDENTS VISITING THE MNSA AND SPARK A CONTINUED INTEREST IN THE NATURAL WORLD IN THEIR LIFESTYLES AND POSSIBLY FUTURE CAREERS. THE HISTORIC BUILDING LOCATED AT THIS SITE HAS HOSTED AROUND 17,000 VISITORS PER YEAR. THE NEW FACILITY WILL OFFER THE OPPORTUNITY TO PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION FOR AN EVEN LARGER NUMBER OF RESIDENTS.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT NOAA'S COMPREHENSIVE OBSERVATION, MODELING, AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. THE PROJECT'S GOALS ARE TO: (1) UNDERSTAND, PREDICT CHANGES IN, AND SHARE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT CLIMATE, WEATHER, OCEANS, AND COASTS; AND (2) CONSERVE AND MANAGE COASTAL AND MARINE ECOSYSTEMS AND RESOURCES. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON PHYSICAL AND ECOLOGICAL VARIABILITY IN THE COUPLED OCEAN-ATMOSPHERE-LAND (EARTH) SYSTEM, GLOBALLY AND IN FOUR FOCUS REGIONS: THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT SYSTEM (CCS); THE US WEST COAST AND THE WESTERN US; THE PACIFIC; AND THE SOUTHERN OCEAN. EMPHASIS IS ON ANALYSIS AND PREDICTION OF PHYSICAL AND BIOGEOCHEMICAL PARAMETERS, ECOSYSTEMS, AND SOCIETAL WELFARE, ALIGNED WITH NOAA'S FOCI ON RESILIENT COMMUNITIES AND ECOSYSTEM-BASED MANAGEMENT.

THE HIGH TECHNOLOGY FOUNDATION WILL BE PROVIDED WITH $2,000,000. THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH THAT WILL LEAD TO THE CONCEPTUALIZATION OF AN INNOVATION AND ENTREPRENEURIAL ECOSYSTEM IN NORTH CENTRAL WEST VIRGINIA INVOLVING THE CLIMATE AND WEATHER SECTOR. THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR WITH THE WEST VIRGINIA HIGH TECHNOLOGY FOUNDATION WILL COORDINATE WITH THE NOAA TECHNOLOGY PARTNERSHIPS OFFICE AS WELL AS THE NOAA OFFICE OF THE CHIEF INFORMATION OFFICER REGARDING POTENTIAL COLLABORATION EFFORTS.

THE MAINE CLIMATE SCIENCE INFORMATION EXCHANGE (MCSIE) IS THE CLIMATE SCIENCE INFORMATION COORDINATION HUB CALLED FOR IN THE STATES MAINE WON'T WAIT CLIMATE ACTION PLAN. MCSIE IS STRUCTURED AS A COORDINATION OFFICE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MAINE WITH A STATEWIDE MISSION OF SERVING AS A GATEWAY TO THE ONGOING RESEARCH AND CRITICAL SCIENCE SUPPORTING THE STATE CLIMATE ACTION PLAN AND ITS IMPLEMENTATION BY THE MAINE CLIMATE COUNCIL, THE LEGISLATURE, AGENCIES, BUSINESSES, COMMUNITIES, AND MAINE CITIZENS. CREATED IN 2022 WITH FEDERAL AND PRIVATE FUNDING SUPPORT, MCSIE FOCUSES ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF DATA ABOUT WHAT CLIMATE CHANGE RESEARCH IS TAKING PLACE IN MAINE, AND WHO IS CONDUCTING THAT RESEARCH. THE OFFICE WORKS TO BUILD CONNECTIONS AMONG RESEARCHERS AND STAKEHOLDERS, SERVING A BOUNDARY-SPANNING FUNCTION TO ASSURE THAT MAINE STAKEHOLDERS ARE INFORMED ABOUT THE SCIENCE THAT IS AVAILABLE AND EMERGING, AND THAT RESEARCHERS ARE INFORMED ABOUT STAKEHOLDER NEEDS. IT WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS BY LEVERAGING THE ADVANCES IN REMOTE SENSING DATA AND PROCESSING IN THE LAST DECADE. IN DOING SO, IT WILL IMPROVE THE ABILITY OF GOVERNMENTS AT ALL LEVELS TO ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE IN AN EQUITABLE AND JUST FASHION. NEW JERSEY COASTAL COMMUNITIES, LIKE MOST US COASTAL COMMUNITIES ARE INCREASINGLY FACED WITH SEVERE THREATS FROM CLIMATE CHANGE, SEA LEVEL RISE AND COASTAL HAZARDS THAT DISPROPORTIONALLY IMPACT DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES. LOCAL GOVERNMENT ACTION IS CRITICAL FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF EFFECTIVE COASTAL RESILIENCE, YET MUNICIPALITIES AND COUNTIES OFTEN LACK THE TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL MEANS TO PROACTIVELY PREPARE FOR AND CONFRONT SEA-LEVEL RISE AND OTHER CLIMATE IMPACTS. THESE DEFICIENCIES ARE FURTHER AMPLIFIED IN SOCIALLY VULNERABLE AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITIES. CLIMATE CHANGE IS EXPECTED TO ADVERSELY IMPACT THE WATER RESOURCES OF TEXAS, ESPECIALLY IN THE DRIER, WESTERN TWO-THIRDS OF THE STATE. HOWEVER, EXCEPT FOR AUSTIN, CLIMATE CHANGE IS NOT CONSIDERED IN LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND STATE WATER-RESOURCE PLANNING. IN THE CASE OF THE CITY OF AUSTINWHICH IS 100 PERCENT RELIANT ON THE HIGHLAND LAKESCLIMATE CHANGE IS EXPECTED TO DECREASE SURFACE-WATER SUPPLIES BY 25 PERCENT IN 50 YEARS AND 50 PERCENT IN 100 YEARS. THE ABSENCE OF CONSIDERING CLIMATE CHANGE IN TEXAS (AND OTHER CONSERVATIVE STATES) IS PRIMARILY DUE TO THE POLITICAL NATURE OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN CONSERVATIVE POLITICS, AND THIS IS NOT EXPECTED TO CHANGE ANY TIME SOON. WE PROPOSE TO PROVIDE THE SCIENCE, POLICY ANALYSIS, AND EDUCATION NEEDED BY STATE LEADERSHIP, THE LEGISLATURE, STATE AGENCIES, LOCAL AND REGIONAL PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, WATER PROVIDERS, COMMUNITIES, AND CITIZENS TO ASSESS HOW CLIMATE CHANGE MAY IMPACT THEIR WATER RESOURCES. THE PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH THE VIRGINIA CLIMATE CENTER TO SERVE AS A CLIMATE EXTENSION SERVICE TO HELP COMMUNITIES IN THE COMMONWEALTH INCREASE RESILIENCE TO THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THIS PILOT PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH THE CENTER IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NORTHERN VIRGINIA REGIONAL COMMISSION, CITY OF FAIRFAX, COUNTY OF FAIRFAX, AND OTHER JURISDICTIONS IN NORTHERN VIRGINIA. THE CENTER WILL PROVIDE PRODUCTS AND SERVICES TO VIRGINIA MUNICIPALITIES AND FIRMS TO ADOPT RISK PREVENTION AND MITIGATION STRATEGIES FOR WISE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABLE ENTREPRENEURSHIP. THE PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF LARGE LIVING CORAL MODULES FOR OUTPLANTING IN A CONCENTRATED AREA OFF WAIKIKI TO ENHANCE SHALLOW-WATER MARINE TOURISM USE CLOSE TO THE TOURISM CENTER OF WAIKIKI. THESE EFFORTS WILL PROVIDE A FREE, MAINTAINED, REEF SNORKELING EXPERIENCE TO HELP RELIEVE INTENSE VISITOR PRESSURE ON THE ISLAND'S NATURAL REEF HABITATS AND TO HELP RE-START THE HAWAIIAN TOURISM INDUSTRY AFTER THE EFFECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. OUTPLANTED MODULES WILL BE GROWN USING EXISTING, ESTABLISHED, AND PROVEN STATE OF HAWAII PROTOCOLS AND PROCEDURES. THIS PROJECT WILL OUTPLANT A MINIMUM COMBINATION EQUIVALENT TO 80 ASSORTED LIVE CORAL MODULES (16 INCHES, BUT POSSIBLY UP TO 1 YARD IN SIZE) AFTER A ONE YEAR PERIOD. THESE OUTPLANTED CORALS WILL BE MAINTAINED AT THE SITE OVER TIME TO PROVIDE FOR AN ALTERNATIVE TO VISITORS USING OTHER NATURAL REEF AREAS FOR RECREATION.

THE PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO SUPPORT MOVING A SMALL RARE HAWAIIAN CORAL ARK TO AN ADJACENT, ALREADY EXISTING, BETTER-HARDENED BUILDING, WITH MORE CONSISTENT ELECTRICAL AND WATER, AND PROVIDE DEDICATED FUNDED SUPPORT FOR THEIR CARE. THE HAWAIIAN ISLANDS ARE HOME TO ABOUT 65 CORAL SPECIES, OF WHICH 25% ARE ENDEMIC TO HAWAII, WITH THE MAJORITY BEING UNCOMMON OR RARE ON OUR REEFS. THERE IS NO REPLACEMENT POOL FOR MANY OF THESE SPECIES, SOME OF WHICH ARE RESTRICTED TO A SINGLE BAY WITHIN THE ENTIRE HAWAIIAN ARCHIPELAGO. A WIDE RANGE OF ENDEMIC FISH AND INVERTEBRATES HAVE CO-EVOLVED WITH OUR ENDEMIC CORALS. RECOGNIZING THAT THE LOSS OF THESE UNIQUE SPECIES COULD HAVE A CASCADING EFFECT ACROSS OUR NATIVE REEF ECOSYSTEMS, HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES CREATED A SMALL RARE HAWAIIAN CORAL ARK PROJECT AS A FORM OF GENE BANK OR INSURANCE POLICY AT ITS EXISTING HAWAII CORAL RESTORATION NURSERY (HCRN), BUT IT IS CONTAINED WITHIN A VULNERABLE PLYWOOD BUILDING ON-SITE. CORAL REEFS AND MARINE RESOURCES ARE VITAL FOR HAWAI'I'S ECONOMY AND CULTURAL IDENTITY, AS THEY SUSTAIN LOCAL FOOD PRODUCTION, RECREATION, JOBS, AND LIVELIHOODS. DESPITE THEIR IMPORTANCE, THE CONDITION OF CORAL REEFS AND NEARSHORE WATERS IN HAWAI'I HAS SIGNIFICANTLY DECLINED OVER THE PAST HALF CENTURY DUE TO A SUITE OF LOCAL AND GLOBAL STRESSORS, INCLUDING OVERFISHING, SEA LEVEL RISE, OCEAN WARMING AND ACIDIFICATION, AND RUN-OFF FROM INCREASED EROSION AND DEVELOPMENT (E.G., SEDIMENT, SEWAGE, PESTICIDES/HERBICIDES, ETC.). THE NATURE CONSERVANCY IS WORKING WITH FEDERAL, STATE, AND COUNTY AGENCY PARTNERS AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES ACROSS MAUI NUI (THE ISLANDS OF MAUI, LANA'I, MOLOKA'I, AND KAHO'OLAWE) AND THE ISLAND OF HAWAII TO ADDRESS THESE THREATS AND INCREASE CORAL COVER, REEF HEALTH, AND FISH ABUNDANCE IN OUR NEARSHORE WATERS. THE PHILLIP AND PATRICIA FROST MUSEUM OF SCIENCE (FROST SCIENCE) RECEIVED A CONGRESSIONAL APPROPRIATION OF $1,150,000 TO ESTABLISH THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR EDUCATION AND CONSERVATION OF FLORIDA'S CORAL REEF.  THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR EDUCATION AND CONSERVATION OF FLORIDA'S CORAL REEF AT FROST SCIENCE WILL BE AN INTERDISCIPLINARY HUB FOR COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH, ACTIONABLE CONSERVATION EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH. LEVERAGING RESOURCES AND EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE AT THE MUSEUM - INCLUDING ITS PUBLIC AQUARIUM, FUNCTIONAL MARINE CONSERVATION LAB, CONFERENCE ROOM SPACE AND RESEARCH VESSEL - THE NEW CENTER WILL PROVIDE UNIQUE OPPORTUNITIES FOR CONTINUOUS EDUCATION, RESEARCH, RESEARCH DISSEMINATION, AND ACTIVE FIELD CONSERVATION OF FLORIDA'S CORAL REEF, WHILE CONNECTING PEOPLE TO MARINE SCIENCE, STEM-BASED EDUCATION, BIODIVERSITY, AND RESTORATION.

THE SPECTACULAR NATURAL BEAUTY OF BISCAYNE BAY THAT DRIVES TOURISM AND ATTRACTS NEARLY THREE MILLION SOUTH FLORIDA RESIDENTS TO ITS SHORES AND WATERS IS THREATENED BY CONTINUING POLLUTION AND THE INCREASING LIKELIHOOD OF HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS. AND RECENT EVENTS INDICATE THAT THE HEALTH OF THE BAY IS RAPIDLY DECLINING. REVERSING THIS TREND REQUIRES DETERMINING THE FACTORS THAT PROMOTE PHYTOPLANKTON BLOOMS AND IDENTIFYING AREAS WHERE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TOWARDS IMPROVING WATER QUALITY SHOULD BE FOCUSED. KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM PROPOSED PHYTOPLANKTON MONITORING, GENETIC METABARCODING, AND METABOLOMIC CHARACTERIZATION TO DETECT ALGAL TOXINS IN COORDINATION WITH A WATER QUALITY MONITORING PROGRAM WILL BE SYNTHESIZED INTO A PUBLICLY-AVAILABLE DATABASE THAT WILL GUIDE RESOURCE MANAGERS IN THE RESPONSIBLE STEWARDSHIP OF BISCAYNE BAY. THE INCREASE OF HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS) IS A GLOBAL CHALLENGE WHICH SEVERELY IMPACTS OUR PUBLIC HEALTH AND ECONOMY. WHILE PHYTOPLANKTON PLAYS AN IMPORTANT ROLE AS THE PRIMARY PRODUCERS IN A BALANCED ECOSYSTEM, TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING CAN BE VERY HARMFUL. NEW JERSEY HAS SEEN SIGNIFICANT INCREASES IN HABS THAT PRODUCES CYANOTOXINS, WHICH CAN BE DANGEROUS FOR HUMANS, PETS, LIVESTOCK, AND WILDLIFE. EXPOSURE TO CYANOTOXINS CAN LEAD TO HARMFUL EFFECTS MAINLY ON THE NERVOUS SYSTEM, THE LIVER, THE KIDNEY, AND THE SKIN. NEW JERSEY GOVERNOR MURPHY LAUNCHED AN INITIATIVE IN LATE 2019 TO MITIGATE AND PREVENT HABS IN THE STATE'S WATERS, BUT THE EFFORTS SLOWED BECAUSE OF THE PANDEMIC AND THE OCCURRENCES OF HABS HAVE INCREASED IN THE FRESHWATERS OF NEW JERSEY SINCE 2020. WITHOUT MITIGATION, THIS TREND IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE WITH INCREASING FREQUENCY AND INTENSITY.  IT IS ESSENTIAL TO EDUCATE THE GENERAL PUBLIC TO IDENTIFY HABS AND TAKE ACTIONS TO REDUCE WATER POLLUTION AND FUTURE BLOOMS. THE

THIS PILOT STUDY WILL FOCUS ON HUMPBACK WHALES IN OREGON WATERS, WITH THE POTENTIAL FOR RESULTS AND OUTCOMES TO BE CONSIDERED FOR APPLICATION TO OTHER LARGE WHALE SPECIES AND/OR FOR OTHER WATERS ON THE U.S WEST COAST.

FISHPONDS ARE TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN AQUACULTURE SITES AND FISHPOND PRACTITIONERS ARE ATTEMPTING TO RECREATE SUSTAINABLE COASTAL FISH FARMING OPERATIONS THAT ONCE THRIVED THROUGHOUT THE ISLANDS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  THIS PROJECT HAS THREE MAIN COMPONENTS. 1)  CONDUCT MULTIPLE COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND DESIGN MEETINGS THAT ENGAGE A NETWORK OF APPROXIMATELY 40 FISHPOND MANAGERS AND COMMUNITY-SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS TO GATHER INSIGHTS AND PERSPECTIVES RELATING TO THE MOST IMPORTANT ENVIRONMENTAL, CLIMATE, OR TECHNOLOGICAL BARRIERS TO EFFECTIVE FISHPOND RESTORATION FOR FOOD PRODUCTION. THIS PROCESS WILL HELP TO INFORM DEVELOPMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL SENSORS. 2) DESIGN, DEVELOP AND DEPLOY ENVIRONMENTAL SENSORS TH

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A NON-LETHAL TOOL TO REDUCE PREDATION ON ESA-LISTED CHINOOK SALMON, THEREBY INCREASING SURVIVAL OF THIS SPECIES WHICH IS A PRIMARY FOOD SOURCE FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES, AND CRITICAL TO THEIR RECOVERY IN THE PUGET SOUND. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A SPECIALIZED DETERRENT SYSTEM, TARGETED ACOUSTIC STARTLE TECHNOLOGY (TAST), THAT MAY ULTIMATELY DECREASE PINNIPED PREDATION AND IMPROVE SALMON SURVIVAL AT THE HIRAM M. CHITTENDEN (BALLARD) LOCKSA SIGNIFICANT BOTTLENECK AREA IN THE CEDAR RIVER SALMON MIGRATION ROUTE.

THE MARINE MAMMAL CENTER (THE CENTER) HAS BECOME A LEADING MARINE MAMMAL HEALTH, RESEARCH, TEACHING HOSPITAL, AND EDUCATION CENTER. THIS PROJECT WILL ENSURE THE CENTERS 24-HOUR RESPONSE HOTLINE AND DISPATCH TEAM BASED IN SAUSALITO CAN MANAGE AND RESPOND TO MORE THAN 10,000 CALLS EACH YEAR ABOUT SICK, INJURED, AND ORPHANED SEALS, SEA LIONS, AND SEA OTTERS, AS WELL AS ENTANGLED AND STRANDED WHALES, DOLPHINS, OTHER CETACEANS, AND SEA TURTLES. THIS PROJECT ALSO WILL ENSURE THE CENTER HAS THE RESOURCES NEEDED TO CARE FOR THE STRANDED MARINE MAMMALS IT BRINGS IN FOR MEDICAL CARE. IN ADDITION TO RESPONDING TO AND SUPPORTING THE MANAGEMENT OF THE STATES NONENDANGERED MARINE MAMMAL SPECIES, THE CENTER WILL CONTINUE SERVING AS A FIRST RESPONDER TO MARINE MAMMAL SPECIES CONSIDERED TO BE ENDANGERED OR THREATENED TO HELP SUPPORT THEIR RECOVERY AND SAVE THEM FROM EXTINCTION.

THERE IS CONSIDERABLE CONCERN ABOUT DECLINING SALMON POPULATIONS, SALMON FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, AND THE ENDANGERED SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALE POPULATION, WHICH DEPENDS ON SALMON AS A PRIMARY FOOD SOURCE. SALMON POPULATION DECLINES HAVE RESULTED FROM NUMEROUS FACTORS. IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER, ONE CAUSE OF POOR SALMON SURVIVAL IS SEA LION PREDATION. SINCE 2002, SEA LIONS IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER HAVE SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACTED STOCKS OF SALMON AND STEELHEAD LISTED AS ENDANGERED AND THREATENED UNDER THE ESA. THIS FUNDING WILL PROVIDE EQUIPMENT FOR TRAPPING, BARGING, HAULING, AND NON-LETHALLY DETERRING CALIFORNIA AND STELLER SEA LIONS.

THE NORTHWEST STRAITS MARINE CONSERVATION INITIATIVE, COMPOSED OF THE NORTHWEST STRAITS COMMISSION, NORTHWEST STRAITS FOUNDATION, AND SEVEN MARINE RESOURCES COMMITTEES, EMPOWERS COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND ADVISES LOCAL DECISION-MAKERS IN ORDER TO PROTECT AND RESTORE THE MARINE ENVIRONMENT OF NORTHWEST WASHINGTON STATE. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH ON-THE-GROUND RESTORATION, EDUCATION, AND MONITORING PROJECTS.

THE PACIFIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION WILL PROVIDE $2,000,000 IN FUNDING TO SUPPORT VESSELS WITH EXISTING ELECTRONIC MONITORING SYSTEMS AS WELL AS GEAR UP NEW VESSELS TO PARTICIPATE IN THE ELECTRONIC MONITORING PROGRAM. PSMFC EXPECTS TO ACCOMPLISH THIS THROUGH SUB-CONTRACTS WITH THE EXISTING ALASKA HARDWARE PROVIDERS, ARCHIPELAGO MARINE RESEARCH AND SALTWATER, INC. CURRENTLY THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 170 FIXED GEAR VESSELS PARTICIPATING IN THIS FISHERY. MANY OF THE SYSTEMS ARE APPROACHING THE USEFUL END LIFE OF THEIR HARDWARE. THIS PROGRAM WOULD REPAIR AND REPLACE SYSTEM COMPONENTS AS NEEDED. IN ADDITION TO EXISTING VESSELS, BETWEEN 25 AND 30 NEW FIXED GEAR VESSELS AND BETWEEN 25 AND 30 NEW TRAWL VESSELS ARE EXPECTED TO JOIN THE ELECTRONIC MONITORING PROGRAM AND THOSE INSTALLATIONS OF NEW SYSTEMS ON VESSELS WILL BE FINANCIALLY SUPPORTED.

THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII'S OFFICE OF INDIGENOUS INNOVATION WILL SUPPORT A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCE AND ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT AND THE NON-PROFIT HUI O HO OHONUA. OBJECTIVES OF THE COLLABORATION ARE TO SCALE EXISTING PUBLIC/PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS FOCUSED ON PROVIDING APPLIED BIOCULTURAL RESTORATION RESEARCH AND MENTORSHIP TO STUDENTS, WHILE SCALING HUI O HO OHONUA'A WORK IN REMEDIATING COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS AND ANCESTRAL FOOD SYSTEMS.

UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGE WILL UTILIZE A CONSORTIUM OF RESEARCH ORGANIZATIONS TO COORDINATE COLLABORATIVELY THROUGH THE KACHEMAK BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE TO CONDUCT STUDIES ON WATERSHED ECOSYSTEM SUPPORT FOR SALMON. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO EXPAND THE SCOPE OF BASELINE RESEARCH ON ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS TO SALMON HEALTH AND PROVIDE FIELD-BASED ENGAGEMENT AND ALTERNATIVE WAYS OF CONVEYING SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ABOUT WATERSHED HABITATS AND SALMON. THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON EXISTING LOCAL PARTNERSHIPS WITH THE KACHEMAK HERITAGE LAND TRUST AND THE NINILCHIK TRIBE AND EXPAND TO NEW PARTNERSHIPS WITH TRIBAL GROUPS IN THE COOK INLET REGION. THE PROJECT INCLUDES DEVELOPING STAKEHOLDER-INFORMED MONITORING OF ECOSYSTEM FEATURES KEY TO SALMON HEALTH, AND A FOCUS ON DEVELOPING DIFFERENT WAYS OF KNOWING WATERSHED STEWARDSHIP THAT INCLUDE TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE, ART, COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND WESTERN ECOLOGICAL SCIENCE.

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE RESEARCH AND PLANNING PHASES OF RESTORATIVE AQUACULTURE INFRASTRUCTURE, HATCHERY SYSTEMS TO SUPPORT STOCK ENHANCEMENT OF FISH FOR HAWAIIAN FISHPONDS.  HAWAIIAN FISHPONDS ARE SUSTAINABLE AQUACULTURE SYSTEMS DEVELOPED OUT OF GENERATIONS OF PLACE-BASED INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE AND INNOVATION IN HAWAII THAT ENHANCE LOCAL FOOD SECURITY.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  THE THREE MAIN ACTIVES SUPPORTED BY THIS PROJECT ARE THE CREATION OF A HATCHERY ADVISORY COMMITTEE, LARGE MEETINGS WITH FISHPOND STAKEHOLDERS AND A HATCHERY FEASIBILITY STUDY. THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY IS TO CONDUCT A FISH HATCHERY FEASIBILITY STUDY TO ASSESS THE PRACTICALITY OF IMPLEMENTING SUCH A SYSTEM. THE HATCHERY ADVISORY COMMITTEE WILL CONSIST OF INDIVIDUALS WITH TECHNICAL EXPERTISE AND FOUNDATIONAL UNDERSTANDING OF BOTH TRADITIONAL FISHPOND AND MODERN AQUACULTURE SYSTEMS TO HELP IDENTIFY STAKEHOLDERS AND RESOURCES NECESSARY FOR SUPPORTING A FISHPOND HATCHERY SYSTEM. THE MEETINGS SUPPORTED

ALASKA RESEARCH CONSORTIUM WILL DEVELOP AN  AMMONIA REFRIGERATION TRAINING PROGRAM AND CERTIFICATION THAT IS TAILORED TO SEAFOOD PROCESSING NEEDS AND CAN BE COMMONLY RECOGNIZED ACROSS SEAFOOD COMPANIES. EACH LEVEL WILL BE DELIVERED BY COMPUTER-BASED TRAINING MODULES AND FACE-TO FACE WORKSHOPS. THIS HYBRID SYSTEM WILL TEACH STUDENTS A PROGRESSION OF SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE SPECIFIC TO AMMONIA-BASED REFRIGERATION IN THE ALASKA SEAFOOD INDUSTRY SECTOR. THESE CERTIFICATION LEVELS WILL BECOME THE NEW STANDARD IN ALASKA, GIVING SEAFOOD COMPANIES A CLEAR UNDERSTANDING OF THE SKILL-LEVEL OF AN EMPLOYEE APPLYING TO WORK IN AMMONIA REFRIGERATION. THE PROGRAM WILL HELP MEET THE NEED FOR SKILLED, AMMONIA REFRIGERATION TRAINED PERSONNEL IN ALASKA.

THE CITY OF MILWAUKIE, OR WILL BE AWARDED $585,000 TO SUPPORT A CHANNEL STUDY TO FACILITATE THE REMOVAL OF KELLOGG DAM. RESTORING FISH PASSAGE AT THE HIGHWAY 99E KELLOGG CREEK BRIDGE, WHICH CROSSES THE DAM, IS THE HIGHEST PRIORITY FISH PASSAGE PROJECT OWNED BY OR DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION.  THIS WORK IS BEING FUNDED AS A CONSOLIDATED APPROPRIATIONS ACT,  2022 NOAA COMMUNITY PROJECT.

TILLAMOOK COUNTY WILL BE AWARDED $2,500,000 TO REMOVE UP TO SIX FAILING COUNTY CULVERTS THAT ARE FISH BARRIERS AND RESTORING SALMONID HABITAT IN UP TO SIX STREAMS FOR UP TO 9.2 MILES OF RESTORED ACCESS IN TILLAMOOK COUNTY, OR. THE PROJECT ENHANCES NOAA'S STRATEGIC PLAN AND MISSION GOALS TO PROTECT, RESTORE, AND MANAGE COASTAL AND OCEAN RESOURCES THROUGH AN ECOSYSTEM APPROACH TO MANAGEMENT.

FOR THE PRIMARY TASK UNDER THIS PROJECT, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY WOULD USE $150,000 TO PURCHASE APPROXIMATELY 150,000 NATIVE, ADULT OYSTERS FROM AQUACULTURE PRODUCERS AND THEN DEPLOY THE OYSTERS AT REEF RESTORATION SITES TOTALING APPROXIMATELY 2 ACRES WITHIN OYSTER SANCTUARIES IN MARYLAND. THESE ACTIONS ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE GOALS OF EXECUTIVE ORDER 13508 AND THE 2014 CHESAPEAKE BAY WATERSHED AGREEMENT TO RESTORE OYSTERS IN CHESAPEAKE BAY. THE PROJECT WOULD PROVIDE FISH HABITAT FOR MANY NOAA TRUST SPECIES AND FORAGE SPECIES. EFFECTS WILL BE INCREASED OYSTER DENSITIES ON THE TARGET SITES, WHICH ARE ANTICIPATED TO BE SELF-SUSTAINING, AND INCREASE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES INCLUDING WATER FILTRATION, FISH HABITAT, AND INCREASED SPAWNING CAPACITY.

THE DIVISION OF CONSERVATION AND RESOURCES ENFORCEMENT'S (DOCARE) MAKAI WATCH PROGRAM ENHANCES PROTECTION OF NEARSHORE AND COASTAL RESOURCES BY PROVIDING COMMUNITY MEMBERS OPPORTUNITIES TO WORK AND INTERACT WITH RESOURCE MANAGERS AND ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS IN THEIR COMMUNITY. SINCE 2013, THE MAKAI WATCH PROGRAM HAS PROVIDED TRAINING TO COMMUNITIES TO RAISE THEIR AWARENESS OF RULES AND REGULATIONS WITH RESPECT TO NATURAL RESOURCES SO THAT COMMUNITY MEMBERS CAN SERVE AS THE "EYES AND EARS" LOOKING OUT FOR THEIR AREA'S RESOURCES. IN RECENT YEARS, THE PROGRAM HAS EXPANDED FROM TRAINING PEOPLE IN A DESIGNATED COMMUNITY TO PROVIDING TRAININGS ON A WIDER SCALE TO EDUCATE ANY MEMBER OF THE PUBLIC WHO WOULD LIKE TO LEARN. CURRENTLY, THERE IS ONLY ONE MAKAI WATCH COORDINATOR BASED ON THE ISLAND OF OAHU, DESPITE COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT ON EACH OF THE NEIGHBOR ISLANDS AS WELL.   THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF TWO NEW ISLAND COORDINATORS, ONE ON MAUI AND ONE ON HAWAI

THE HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES IS RECOMMENDED TO RECEIVE $2.1M TO ADVANCE COASTAL STEWARDSHIP OF FISHERIES AND CORAL REEFS AT SITES ON THE HAWAII ISLAND THROUGH THE INTEGRATED EFFORTS OF COMMUNITY, STATE, FEDERAL, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONAL PARTNERS. THIS PROJECT BUILDS LOCAL CAPACITY FOR EFFECTIVE SCIENCE-BASED AND COMMUNITY-SUPPORTED CORAL REEF MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION THROUGH THE EMPOWERMENT OF LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO CO-MANAGE NEARSHORE REEFS AND FISHERIES, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF IN-SITU EXPERTISE AND EX-SITU NURSERY FACILITIES TO INCREASE THE HEALTH, ABUNDANCE, AND RESILIENCE OF HAWAII'S CORAL REEFS. THIS PROJECT CAN SERVE AS AN INCUBATOR FOR CORAL REEF RESTORATION SCIENCE AND DRIVE THE INNOVATION OF IN-WATER MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT ARE EFFECTIVE, SCALABLE, CULTURALLY-APPROPRIATE, AND LOCALLY-RELEVANT.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO BUILD A NEW COALITION FOR CONNECTICUT GHOST FISHING PREVENTION EFFORTS, SUPPORT THE INDUSTRY DIRECTLY, AND IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF OTHER FISHERIES, WHICH WILL BE DONE THROUGH (1) ESTABLISHING CONNECTICUT'S FIRST TRAP RETRIEVAL PROGRAM, (2) RECRUITING AND MENTORING FIELD STAFF FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS IN THE SCIENCES AND INDUSTRY, (3) BUILDING REGIONAL EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES AND CONDUCTING OUTREACH, AND (4) CONDUCTING SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH TO QUANTIFY THE IMPACT OF LOST AND ABANDONED LOBSTER TRAPS ON THE ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES OF THE SOUND.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ENGAGE MORE OF THE NEW HAMPSHIRE VERTICAL LINE FISHERY PARTICIPANTS IN ATLANTIC LARGE WHALE ISSUES AND POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS THROUGH OUTREACH METHODS SUCH AS DEVELOPED MATERIALS AND MEETINGS WITH THE INDUSTRY TO OUTLINE THE CURRENT ISSUES AND OBTAIN INPUT ON REMEDIES THAT CAN BE BROUGHT FORWARD AT ATLANTIC LARGE WHALE TAKE REDUCTION TEAM MEETINGS. THE NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS TO MEETINGS AND RECEIVED COMMENTS WILL BE RECORDED TO SHOW LEVEL OF ENGAGEMENT. ADDITIONAL SURVEYS WILL BE DEVELOPED TO MEASURE THE KNOWLEDGE OF THE ISSUES AND INCREASE RESPONSE RATES.

THE MUNICIPAL ALLIANCE FOR ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT (MAAM) IS A REGIONAL ORGANIZATION CREATED BY INTERMUNICIPAL AGREEMENT AMONG SEVEN (7) COASTAL NEW HAMPSHIRE CITIES AND TOWNS (ROCHESTER, DOVER, PORTSMOUTH, EXETER, NEWINGTON, MILTON, AND ROLLINSFORD) WHICH OWN EIGHT (8) WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITIES THAT DISCHARGE TO THE GREAT BAY WATERSHED AND ARE SUBJECT TO THE 2021 GREAT BAY TOTAL NITROGEN GENERAL NPDES PERMIT.  THE ORGANIZATION WAS FORMED TO COLLECTIVELY IMPLEMENT ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PLANS INCLUDING SPECIFIC ACTIONS TO STUDY, MONITOR AND IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF THE GREAT BAY ESTUARY, BEYOND WHAT THE COMMUNITIES COULD DO INDIVIDUALLY WITH PARTNERS UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE, THE PISCATAQUA REGION ESTUARIES PARTNERSHIP (PREP), THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, AND THE CONSERVATION LAW FOUNDATION, THE MAAM SEEKS TO ADDRESS FOUR OBJECTIVES:    1.      EELGRASS BED RESTORATION. 2.      OYSTER REEF RESTORATION. 3.      MONITORING THE EFFICACY OF OYSTER REEF AND EELGRASS BED RESTORATION. 4.

THIS INITIATIVE WILL BUILD A NATIONAL CONSORTIUM OF FISHING COMMUNITIES, RESEARCHERS, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE THAT WILL COLLABORATE TO (1) ACCELERATE TRANSDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH RELATED TO SMALL-SCALE FISHERIES AND LOCAL AND REGIONAL SEAFOOD SYSTEMS; (2) CREATE DYNAMIC TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR A DIVERSE COHORT OF GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS; (3) FACILITATE NETWORK BUILDING AND COLLABORATION ACROSS CONSORTIUM MEMBERS; AND (4) PROVIDE TRAINING, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND RESOURCES TO STRENGTHEN SEAFOOD OPERATIONS ENGAGED IN LOCAL AND REGIONAL SEAFOOD SYSTEMS, WITH A FOCUS ON OPERATIONS BASED IN OR SERVING RURAL, LOW INCOME, AND/OR LOW FOOD ACCESS AREAS.

THE MCKENZIE RIVER SUB-BASIN, LIKE MANY IN THE WILLAMETTE BASIN, IS LARGELY DEVOID OF THE LARGE WOODY DEBRIS THAT WOULD HAVE CHARACTERIZED THE BASIN PRIOR TO EUROPEAN SETTLEMENT. THE LACK OF INSTREAM WOOD HAS REDUCED THE FREQUENCY OF DEEP POOLS, THE AMOUNT OF COMPLEX COVER, AND LIMITED THE STORAGE OF SEDIMENT WITHIN THE MCKENZIE RIVER. THESE CHANGES HAVE IMPACTED SPRING CHINOOK SALMON, BULL TROUT AND MANY OTHER NATIVE SPECIES THAT DEPEND ON COMPLEX RIVERINE HABITATS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE ADDITION OF A TOTAL OF MORE THAN 3,200 PIECES OF LARGE WOOD THROUGHOUT THE 70 ACRE PROJECT AREA WILL HELP FACILITATE THE NATURAL PROCESSES OF GRAVEL, SEDIMENT, AND NUTRIENT DEPOSITION THAT HAS BEEN LOST DUE TO THE REMOVAL OF INSTREAM WOOD, ORIGINALLY TO ENABLE THE TRANSPORT OF HARVESTED LOGS DOWNSTREAM.

THE PORT OF SAN DIEGO (PORT) IS SEEKING TO IMPLEMENT A NATURE-BASED SHORELINE SOLUTION ALONG HARBOR ISLAND PARK SHORELINE IN SAN DIEGO BAY. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL REPLACE APPROXIMATELY 450 LINEAR FEET OF EXISTING ROCK REVETMENT (RIPRAP) SHORELINE WITH AN INNOVATIVE, SUSTAINABLE ALTERNATIVE THAT IMPROVES LOCAL HABITAT VALUE AND BIODIVERSITY, PROVIDES WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS AND ADDITIONAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, AND BOOSTS RESILIENCY WHILE MAINTAINING THE REQUIRED STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY PRESENT ALONG THE SHORELINE. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE AN INNOVATIVE SUSTAINABLE RESPONSE TO AN EXISTING ARMORED SHORELINE THAT HAS TRADITIONALLY PRIORITIZED STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY OVER ENVIRONMENTAL VALUE.

THIS 12-MONTH PROJECT HAS FOUR OBJECTIVES.  IT WILL 1.      SUPPORT EXISTING, AND HIRE, NEW STAFF AND PARTIALLY FUND A NEW RESEARCH VESSEL TO ENSURE DELIVERY OF RESEARCH OBJECTIVES, AS WELL AS ADDITIONAL FIELD-BASED RESEARCH RELATED TO ENVIRONMENTAL MITIGATION AND OFFSHORE WIND. 2.      EXPAND EXISTING ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY RESEARCH ON THE SPATIAL ECOLOGY AND HABITAT USE AND MOVEMENT OF HIGHLY MIGRATORY SPECIES TRANSITING THROUGH THE SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND WIND ENERGY AREAS, AND DIVERSIFY SPECIES MONITORING TO INCLUDE SEA TURTLES AND OTHER OPPORTUNISTIC SPECIES OF COMMERCIAL AND/OR CONSERVATION CONCERN.  3.      USE PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED AERIAL SURVEY DATA TO EXPAND QUANTITATIVE RISK ASSESSMENTS OF THE POTENTIAL EFFECTS OF OFFSHORE WIND CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION ON PROTECTED SPECIES (E.G., NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALE), AND CONTRIBUTE TO DEVELOPING SOLUTIONS TO MITIGATE RISK. 4.      RECRUIT TECHNICAL AND PROGRAM MANAGEMENT STAFF FOR EXPERTISE INTO OPERATIONS OF THE BLUESWELL INCUBATOR

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE MEETING PLANNING AND COMMUNICATIONS SUPPORT WITH ALL SEVEN LOBSTER ZONE COUNCILS AND INDUSTRY ASSOCIATIONS TO SHARE INFORMATION AND FACILITATE DISCUSSION TO UNDERSTAND THE NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALE CONSERVATION FRAMEWORK (CF) FOR FEDERAL FISHERIES IN THE GREATER ATLANTIC REGION UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, AND ITS IMPLICATIONS. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE WORK WOULD INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS, MULTIPLE ROUNDS OF MEETINGS BASED ON THE EXISTING CO-MANAGEMENT STRUCTURE IN THE MAINE LOBSTER FISHERY, AS WELL AS UTILIZATION OF SURVEY TOOLS TO REACH ADDITIONAL PARTICIPANTS AND CREATE OUTREACH MATERIALS FOR INDUSTRY MEMBERS TO REVIEW OUTSIDE OR IN LIEU OF ATTENDING MEETINGS.

THE PROJECT TITLE IS "EXPANDING MEANINGFUL STEM & ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION ON THE NATIONAL AQUARIUM'S WATERFRONT CAMPUS." THE PROJECT PERIOD IS FROM JULY 1, 2022 TO JUNE 30, 2024. THE PROJECT WOULD USE $332,000 TO: 1) ENGAGE 700 BALTIMORE SIXTH GRADE STUDENTS IN A "MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE (MWEE)" 2) COLLECT DATA FROM STUDENTS WHO PARTICIPATE IN THE MWEE 3) DESIGN INTERPRETATION AND INTERACTIVE ELEMENTS TO FACILITATE STEM LEARNING AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND 4) DEVELOP A PLAN FOR THE INFRASTRUCTURE OF A FLOATING WETLANDS COMPLEX ADJACENT TO THE AQUARIUM AND LEARNING SPACES ON THE PLATFORM.

BIGELOW LABORATORY FOR OCEAN SCIENCES HAS REQUESTED FEDERAL FUNDING (CONMUNITY FUNDING) IN THE AMOUNT OF $89,000 TO SUPPORT PART OF 2022-2023 ACTIVITIES FOR AN ANNUAL PROGRAM OF MARINE EDUCATION ESTABLISHED THREE DECADES AGO.  THROUGH TWO, FREE, WEEK-LONG BLOOM PROGRAMS ("BIGELOW LABORATORY ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE") OVER THE COURSE OF ONE YEAR, BIGELOW LABORATORY FOR OCEAN SCIENCES: 1) ARMS 10 MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL SCIENCE TEACHERS WITH THE SKILLS AND EQUIPMENT THEY NEED TO GIVE THEIR STUDENTS MORE MEANINGFUL AQUATIC SCIENCE EXPERIENCES IN SCHOOL THROUGH THE BLOOM EDUCATORS PROGRAM, AND 2) INSPIRES 16 MAINE HIGH SCHOOL JUNIORS TO PURSUE STUDIES AND CAREERS IN STEM THROUGH THE KELLER BLOOM STUDENT PROGRAM. THESE ANNUAL PROGRAMS, COLLECTIVELY KNOWN AS "THE BLOOMS", STRENGTHEN HOW STUDENTS AND TEACHERS LINK THEIR SCIENCE CLASSROOMS TO REAL WORLD ISSUES LIKE CLIMATE CHANGE, WATER QUALITY, FISHERIES, AND CONSERVATION. THE SCANNING HIGH-RESOLUTION INTERFEROMETER SOUNDER (S-HIS) AIRCRAFT INSTRUMENT, DEVELOPED AT UW-SSEC, HAS DEMONSTRATED STATE-OF-THE-ART PERFORMANCE AND UNPRECEDENTED ROBUSTNESS AND RELIABILITY OVER 20+ YEARS OF OPERATION AND IS RECOGNIZED AS A KEY GOVERNMENT ASSET AS AN INFRARED CALIBRATION REFERENCE STANDARD THAT IS CRUCIAL FOR WEATHER SATELLITE CALIBRATION VALIDATION AND AN IMPORTANT TOOL FOR STUDYING WEATHER PHENOMENON, SUCH AS HURRICANES AND SEVERE STORMS. DUE TO ITS AGE, A REPLACEMENT OF THE S-HIS WITH IS BECOMING NECESSARY. THIS PROJECT BEGINS THAT PROCESS THROUGH BREADBOARD TESTING OF KEY SUBSYSTEMS TO REDUCE PROGRAMMATIC AND TECHNICAL RISK OF THE EVENTUAL REPLACEMENT INSTRUMENT DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. ULTIMATELY, THE NEW S-HIS WILL BE CAPABLE OF PLAYING A KEY ROLE IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND VALIDATION OF THE FUTURE GENERATIONS OF WEATHER SATELLITES.
